name: Big Springs
description: Located at the top of the bottom-up route of the Narrows, this spot involves a 4.5-mile river walk one direction and features impressive canyon views and waterfalls.
tips: Be prepared for a brutal hike of approximately 10.5 miles round trip.
Expect deep water sections even during dry months.
Allow at least 3+ hours for the hike one way.

name: Road 9 (Serpentine Section)
description: A scenic, winding section of Road 9 near the western entrance that offers sweeping canyon views and various pull-off parking areas for photography.
tips: Use the designated parking areas throughout the serpentine drive to stop safely
A standard smartphone camera is sufficient to capture these views
February is a great time to visit for low crowds and pleasant weather

name: Towers of the Virgin
description: A prominent collection of peaks that provides excellent opportunities for capturing dappled light across the cliff faces.
tips: Look for instances of dappled light to add texture and interest to the cliff faces.

name: Angel's Landing
description: A prominent sandstone monolith towering 5,785 feet above sea level, providing one of the most iconic silhouettes in Zion National Park.
tips: The peak can be photographed from the comfort of the Virgin River.
The hike to the top is exhilarating and offers a world-class view of the canyon below.

name: Zion-Mount Carmel Tunnel
description: A long, dark tunnel with carved-out openings that provide brief, framed views of the park's interior.
tips: Stopping your car inside the tunnel is strictly prohibited
For the best photography, visit the eastern side of the tunnel where there is a parking area and a hiking trail that overlooks it

name: Great White Throne
description: An iconic monolith in Zion Canyon that is particularly photogenic during the fall when surrounded by changing leaves.
tips: Position maple trees at the bottom of the frame to anchor the image with the monolith at the top.

name: Canyon Overlook
description: One of the most accessible overlooks in the park, offering a panoramic view of the western canyons from the eastern end of the Mount Carmel Tunnel.
tips: The trail is a short 1/4 mile hike with about 200 feet of elevation gain
Parking at the trailhead is very limited; use the overflow parking area located shortly after the tunnel exit if needed

name: The Watchman
description: One of the most famous landmarks in the park, located near the south entrance, catching light at both the beginning and end of the day.
tips: At sunrise, focus on the very tip of the mountain as it catches the first light.
This is an ideal spot for beginners due to the manageable compositions.

name: Observation Point
description: A central overlook that provides a massive view of the northern canyon area, distinct from the view at Canyon Overlook.
tips: The original trailhead is closed due to a rock fall
Access the viewpoint via an alternate route starting outside the eastern entrance of Zion
The alternate trail involves driving on dirt roads but the hike is less strenuous than the original

name: The Narrows
description: A world-famous slot canyon where photographers can work with bounce light and river reflections.
tips: June is the best month for deep canyons like this due to the dry conditions.
During monsoon season (July-September), look for dramatic clouds and weather.

name: The Narrows (Trailhead Start)
description: The most famous hike in Zion, featuring towering canyon walls and the Virgin River running through the base.
tips: Dress in layers and wear waterproof socks if visiting in cold months like November
Check weather conditions for flash flood risks before entering the canyon

name: Eagle Crags
description: Located just outside the main canyon, this spot offers grand vistas and is excellent for capturing dramatic weather events like rainbows.
tips: Visit during periods of dramatic weather for a chance to capture rainbows near the crags.

name: Thor’s Hammer
description: The most famous and unique hoodoo rock formation in Bryce Canyon National Park.
tips: Try to pair a sun star with the hoodoo at sunrise to create a stunner image.

name: The Narrows (Waterfall Section)
description: A section near the beginning of the Narrows hike featuring a scenic waterfall along the canyon wall.
tips: Rent dry suits from outfitters outside the western entrance for winter hiking
Bring flashlights or headlamps if you plan to be out late, as the canyon and parking lots have no lights

name: Pa' rus Trail
description: A flat, paved trail following the river that provides easy access to views of the canyon walls.
tips: Stick to this trail if you are a beginner, as the compositions are easier to put together near the mouth of the canyon.

name: Wall Street
description: An iconic area of switchbacks that descend into the Bryce Canyon amphitheater.
tips: Descend into the canyon to look up and capture the scale of the towering hoodoos.

name: Riverside Walkway
description: A paved half-mile walkway that leads to the start of the Narrows, providing beautiful views of the Virgin River and canyon floor.
tips: This is one of the best spots to view fall foliage in the park during November
You can access beach areas along the river from this walkway

name: Court of the Patriarchs
description: A set of three sandstone peaks that catch light shortly after the initial sunrise.
tips: Note that these peaks do not catch the very first light, but are illuminated shortly after.

name: Zion Canyon (Virgin River)
description: The main oasis of the park where the river creates a lush environment against red rock monoliths.
tips: Capture lime green Cottonwoods in spring or yellow foliage in the fall for great color contrast with the red rocks.

name: Zion Canyon (Lower Areas)
description: The lower sections of the park canyon where autumn colors are most vibrant against the red rocks.
tips: Target the lower areas of the park for the best fall foliage views compared to the higher elevations

name: The Subway
description: A unique slot canyon that is best photographed in the middle of summer when the light reaches deep into the canyon.
tips: June is the optimal month for grand landscape shots in deep canyons like the Subway.

name: Checkerboard Mesa
description: A unique geological formation near the eastern entrance featuring a distinct grid-like pattern on the mountain surface.
tips: Use the dedicated overlook on Road 9 near the eastern entrance for the best photo opportunity

name: West Temple
description: A massive peak near the south entrance of the park known for its early morning light.
tips: One of the few peaks in Zion that catches the true first light of sunrise.

name: Zion Canyon Scenic Drive
description: The primary canyon road providing access to the park's most famous trailheads including Angels Landing and the Narrows.
tips: Turn off Road 9 before the serpentine section to access this drive if coming from the west

name: East Temple
description: A prominent peak that is visible from many parts of the park and catches light at both ends of the day.
tips: Plan your shoot to capture the light as it hits the upper sections of the temple during golden hour.

name: West Rim Trail (Angels Landing Viewpoint)
description: A viewpoint about half a mile into the hike towards Angels Landing that offers a lower-elevation perspective of the northern canyon.
tips: This section of the trail is scenic and relatively easy before the steep rise and narrow chains of the summit hike
Use this spot for views of the canyon floor if you aren't doing the full technical hike

name: Bridge Mountain
description: A large mountain where different faces catch light at different times of the day.
tips: The backside catches light at sunrise, while the main face catches light at sunset.

name: The Narrows (Cascading Springs)
description: A photogenic spot within the first 500 feet of the Narrows where water cascades down the massive canyon walls into the river.
tips: Look up from this spot to truly capture the scale of the canyon walls in your photos

name: Mt. Kinesave
description: A peak located near Springdale that provides a stunning backdrop during the late afternoon.
tips: This is one of the primary mountains that catches direct light during sunset.

name: The Narrows (Deep Canyon Interior)
description: Located approximately 2 miles into the Narrows, this section features more rugged, rocky terrain and deeper water.
tips: Be prepared to navigate waist or chest-deep water depending on the season
Dry suits are essential for staying safe and warm in these deeper, colder sections
